title: Non-Conformity Management
legalBasis: EU Regulation (EC) No 852/2004 on HACCP and corrective actions; ISO 22000 Food Safety Management Systems; Spanish health authority guidelines on incident management and corrective action
summary:
Non-conformity management is the systematic process of identifying, documenting, addressing, and preventing food safety and quality failures. A non-conformity occurs whenever food safety or quality standards are not met — this includes critical limit breaches at Critical Control Points, product not meeting specifications, customer complaints related to food safety or quality, inspection findings, adverse microbiological test results, or any other deviation from established procedures or requirements.

Effective non-conformity management is a fundamental requirement of HACCP-based food safety systems under EU Regulation 852/2004. When monitoring indicates that a Critical Control Point is not under control, corrective action must be taken immediately regarding both the affected product and the cause of the deviation. Beyond regulatory compliance, effective non-conformity management prevents minor issues from becoming major problems, demonstrates commitment to food safety and continuous improvement, and provides valuable data for system optimization.

The non-conformity management process involves: detection and documentation of the non-conformity, immediate containment to prevent unsafe product reaching customers, investigation of root cause, implementation of corrective actions to address both the immediate issue and the underlying cause, verification that corrective actions are effective, and preventive actions to ensure the same problem does not recur. Every non-conformity is an opportunity to learn and improve — organizations that manage non-conformities effectively build stronger, more resilient food safety systems.
keyPoints: Non-conformities include any deviation from food safety or quality standards, procedures, or specifications
Immediate action is required to protect customer safety: isolate affected product and assess food safety risk
All non-conformities must be documented with details of what occurred, when, where, and initial actions taken
Root cause investigation determines why the non-conformity occurred, not just what happened
Corrective actions address both the immediate problem and the underlying cause to prevent recurrence
Verification confirms that corrective actions are effective and the problem is resolved
Trend analysis of non-conformities identifies systematic issues requiring preventive action
Non-conformity records provide evidence of food safety system effectiveness and continuous improvement

sections.heading: 1. Understanding Non-Conformities in Food Safety
sections.content:
A non-conformity is any failure to meet a specified requirement. In food safety management, requirements come from multiple sources: legal requirements (food safety regulations, hygiene standards), HACCP plan requirements (critical limits, monitoring procedures), internal standards and specifications (quality standards, procedural requirements), and customer requirements (contractual specifications, special dietary needs). Non-conformities range from minor procedural deviations with no food safety impact to serious failures with immediate public health risk.

It is essential to distinguish between different severities of non-conformity. Critical non-conformities pose immediate food safety risk — for example, pathogen detection in ready-to-eat food, critical limit breach at a CCP with no corrective action taken, or breakdown of temperature control for extended periods. Major non-conformities may not pose immediate safety risk but indicate serious system deficiencies — for example, absence of documented HACCP procedures, repeated minor violations indicating systemic problems, or failure to respond to previous non-conformities. Minor non-conformities are isolated incidents with no immediate safety impact but requiring correction — for example, a single missing temperature record, a minor deviation from procedure with no product impact, or documentation gaps.

The severity classification determines the urgency and extent of response required. Critical non-conformities demand immediate action including product isolation, risk assessment, and potentially product destruction and customer notification. Major non-conformities require comprehensive corrective action and system review. Minor non-conformities require correction and monitoring to ensure they do not become recurring problems. All non-conformities, regardless of severity, should be documented and analyzed for trends.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Sources of Non-Conformity Detection
subsections.content:
Non-conformities may be detected through multiple mechanisms. Internal monitoring detects non-conformities during routine HACCP monitoring — for example, temperature checks revealing food outside safe temperature ranges, or visual inspection identifying contaminated ingredients. Staff reports capture observations by any employee who notices problems — encouraging staff to report concerns requires a non-punitive culture where reporting is valued. Customer complaints, particularly those relating to food safety or quality issues, are important non-conformity sources that must be documented and investigated.

Internal audits and management reviews systematically evaluate system compliance and identify procedural deviations or documentation gaps. Microbiological testing results revealing non-compliance indicate process control failures requiring investigation. Official inspections by health authorities may identify non-conformities that internal systems missed. Supplier notifications of product recalls or quality issues with supplied ingredients trigger non-conformity investigations. Each detection source provides different information — a comprehensive system captures non-conformities from all sources and manages them through a consistent process.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Common Non-Conformities in Hospitality
subsections.content:
Temperature control failures are among the most common non-conformities in hospitality: hot food below 65°C, cold food above 8°C, inadequate cooling of cooked food, or refrigeration equipment malfunction. Cross-contamination events include raw food contact with ready-to-eat food, use of same equipment for raw and cooked without cleaning between, or pest contamination. Personal hygiene violations might be food handlers working while ill, inadequate handwashing, or inappropriate attire (no hair restraint, jewelry worn).

Documentation non-conformities include missing monitoring records, undocumented corrective actions, or expired training certifications. Supplier and receiving non-conformities include acceptance of products at incorrect temperatures, products past use-by dates, or undocumented supplier approval. Cleaning and sanitation failures include inadequate cleaning verification, equipment not cleaned as scheduled, or chemical contamination. Allergen management failures such as missing allergen information, cross-contact during preparation, or incorrect allergen communication are serious non-conformities requiring immediate correction.

subsections.heading: 1.3 The Cost of Ignoring Non-Conformities
subsections.content:
Unaddressed non-conformities have serious consequences. From a food safety perspective, ignored problems can escalate into foodborne illness outbreaks affecting customers, damage business reputation and customer trust, and result in legal liability and financial penalties. Regulatory consequences include enforcement actions from health authorities, potential business closure, and loss of certifications or approvals. Financial impacts include product waste from having to discard contaminated food, lost revenue during closures or reputation recovery, increased insurance premiums, and costs of outbreak investigation and management.

Culturally, organizations that tolerate non-conformities develop poor food safety culture where problems are hidden rather than addressed, staff lose trust in management commitment to safety, and continuous improvement stagnates. Conversely, organizations that take all non-conformities seriously, regardless of severity, build strong safety cultures where problems are surfaced and solved, staff are engaged in improvement, and systems become progressively more robust. The investment in effective non-conformity management is far less than the cost of the problems it prevents.

sections.heading: 2. Immediate Response — Containment and Risk Assessment
sections.content:
When a non-conformity is detected, the immediate priority is protecting customer safety. This requires rapid assessment of food safety risk and containment of any affected product to prevent unsafe food reaching customers. The immediate response phase focuses on what action is needed right now, before investigating why the problem occurred. Speed is essential — delayed containment allows unsafe food to reach customers, potentially causing illness.

The person detecting the non-conformity must know what to do immediately without waiting for manager approval. This requires clear procedures, training, and empowerment. A line cook who discovers that hot holding equipment has failed and food temperature has fallen must immediately remove the food from service without needing to find the manager. The manager can later investigate why the equipment failed and how to prevent recurrence, but the immediate action is preventing unsafe food from being served.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Immediate Containment Actions
subsections.content:
Containment means physically separating affected product from products that may be served to customers. Remove affected product from production areas, service areas, or storage. Place in a clearly marked holding area (labeled 'HOLD — Do Not Use' or similar). Use distinctive containers or labels to prevent accidental use. If the entire batch or production run is potentially affected, hold all of it pending investigation. Document what product was affected (product identity, quantity, batch or lot numbers if applicable) and when it was placed on hold.

For non-conformities detected during service, immediate decisions about food already served may be necessary. If food has already been served to customers and food safety risk exists, consider whether customer notification is warranted. For critical non-conformities (e.g., allergen cross-contamination in food served to customer with known allergy), immediate customer notification is required. Document which customers may have been affected, when food was served, and what actions were taken. This information is critical if customers subsequently report illness.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Food Safety Risk Assessment
subsections.content:
Assess the food safety risk of the non-conformity to determine appropriate response. Consider: What hazard is involved (microbiological, chemical, physical, allergen)? What is the likelihood of the hazard causing harm? What is the severity of potential harm? Who might be affected (general population vs vulnerable groups)? Can the hazard be eliminated before service (e.g., through cooking or reheating)?

For example, if hot food fell below 65°C but remained above 55°C for less than 1 hour, microbiological risk may be low and the food might be safely reheated to 75°C and served. However, if food was in the danger zone (5-63°C) for more than 2 hours, bacterial growth may have produced toxins that survive reheating, requiring food disposal. If raw chicken contacted ready-to-eat salad, the salad must be discarded as cross-contamination risk cannot be eliminated. Document the risk assessment rationale for decisions made about affected product.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Disposition of Non-Conforming Product
subsections.content:
Based on risk assessment, decide the fate of affected product. Options include: release for intended use if investigation determines product is safe and meets requirements (minimal risk non-conformities only); rework or reprocessing if the non-conformity can be corrected (e.g., reheating under-temperature food, re-cleaning inadequately cleaned equipment); release for alternative use where appropriate (e.g., food not meeting quality standards for customer service might be used for staff meals if it is safe); or disposal if product is unsafe or cannot be adequately corrected.

Document the disposition decision and implement it immediately. Food designated for disposal must be clearly marked and disposed of in a way that prevents accidental use or consumption. Some establishments use food waste bins with locking lids or denaturing (adding a non-toxic dye or soap) to prevent disposal-destined food from being retrieved. Never attempt to 'hide' non-conforming product by mixing it with conforming product — this violates food safety principles and legal requirements. The cost of discarding non-conforming food is the cost of maintaining food safety standards.

sections.heading: 3. Documentation and Investigation
sections.content:
Once immediate containment is complete, comprehensive documentation and investigation begin. Documentation serves multiple purposes: it provides a record of what occurred and how it was handled, it supports investigation of root causes, it demonstrates compliance with HACCP requirements for corrective action, and it creates data for trend analysis and system improvement. Investigation determines why the non-conformity occurred so that corrective actions can address underlying causes, not just symptoms.

Documentation should be completed as soon as possible while details are fresh. Use a standardized non-conformity report form to ensure consistent information capture. Include objective, factual information — what happened, when, where, who was involved, what immediate actions were taken. Avoid subjective language or assigning blame. The goal is to understand and fix the problem, not to punish individuals. In cultures where non-conformity reporting triggers punishment, staff hide problems rather than reporting them, allowing small issues to become large ones.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Non-Conformity Report Content
subsections.content:
A comprehensive non-conformity report should include: unique identification number and date/time of detection; description of the non-conformity (what requirement was not met, specific details of what occurred); severity classification (critical, major, minor); location where non-conformity occurred; product or process affected; person who detected the non-conformity; immediate actions taken (containment, product disposition); quantity of affected product; and potential food safety or quality impact.

Attach supporting documentation where relevant: photographs of the problem, monitoring records showing the deviation, laboratory reports for microbiological non-conformities, or supplier documentation for ingredient issues. For customer complaints, attach complaint details including customer contact information, when and what food was consumed, and symptoms or concerns reported. Thorough documentation at this stage provides the information needed for effective investigation and corrective action.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Root Cause Analysis
subsections.content:
Root cause analysis determines why the non-conformity occurred, going beyond immediate causes to identify underlying system deficiencies. Use structured investigation methods such as the '5 Whys' technique: repeatedly ask 'why did this happen?' until the fundamental cause is identified. For example: 'Why was food held at incorrect temperature? Because the hot holding equipment failed. Why did it fail? Because the heating element burned out. Why did the heating element burn out? Because the equipment was not maintained according to schedule. Why was maintenance not performed? Because there is no documented maintenance schedule and responsibility was not assigned.'

Other investigation tools include fishbone diagrams (Ishikawa) mapping potential causes across categories (people, process, equipment, materials, environment, management), fault tree analysis for complex systems, or timeline reconstruction for incidents involving multiple factors. The investigation should identify not just what failed, but why controls that should have prevented or detected the failure did not work. Often, multiple contributing factors are involved — effective corrective action may need to address several underlying causes.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Investigation Depth and Timeliness
subsections.content:
Investigation depth should be proportionate to non-conformity severity. Critical non-conformities require comprehensive investigation: detailed timeline reconstruction, interviews with involved personnel, review of all relevant procedures and records, and possibly external expert assistance. Major non-conformities require thorough investigation identifying all contributing factors. Minor isolated non-conformities may require only basic investigation sufficient to prevent recurrence.

Investigations should be completed promptly while evidence is available and memories are fresh — ideally within 24-48 hours for critical non-conformities, within a week for major non-conformities, and within two weeks for minor non-conformities. Assign investigation responsibility clearly: the manager, HACCP coordinator, or quality manager depending on non-conformity severity. Document investigation findings including identified root causes, contributing factors, and whether the non-conformity is isolated or indicates systematic problems. Use findings to inform corrective action planning.

sections.heading: 4. Corrective and Preventive Actions
sections.content:
Corrective actions address the immediate non-conformity and its root causes to prevent recurrence. Preventive actions go further, identifying and addressing potential problems before they occur. EU Regulation 852/2004 requires that when HACCP monitoring indicates a CCP is not under control, corrective action must be taken. Effective corrective action must address both the product (what do we do with the affected product?) and the process (how do we prevent this happening again?).

Corrective actions should be specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART). Vague actions like 'improve training' are insufficient — effective actions specify exactly what will be done, by whom, by when. For example: 'Develop standardized training module on temperature control procedures; deliver to all food handlers by [date]; assess competence through demonstration; document training completion; verify effectiveness through temperature record audit within 30 days.' The more specific the action plan, the more likely it is to be implemented effectively.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Types of Corrective Actions
subsections.content:
Corrective actions vary depending on the root cause. For equipment failures, actions might include immediate repair or replacement, implementation of preventive maintenance schedules, or upgrade to more reliable equipment. For procedural failures, revise procedures to make requirements clearer, simplify procedures to make compliance easier, or add verification steps to catch deviations earlier. For training deficiencies, provide refresher training, modify training content to address identified gaps, or increase frequency of competency assessment.

For design or layout issues, modify facility layout to prevent cross-contamination, upgrade equipment to improve process control, or install additional monitoring equipment for better visibility. For management system failures, improve monitoring procedures, increase audit frequency, or enhance management review processes. For cultural issues, reinforce leadership commitment to food safety, improve communication channels for reporting concerns, or recognize and reward food safety-positive behaviors. The corrective action must be matched to the root cause — training alone will not fix an equipment problem, and new equipment will not fix a culture problem.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Implementing Corrective Actions
subsections.content:
Assign clear responsibility for implementing each corrective action. One person should be accountable for ensuring the action is completed, even if others perform parts of the work. Set realistic timelines that balance urgency with practical constraints — critical issues require immediate action, while complex system changes may need longer implementation periods. Document the action plan including: specific actions to be taken, person responsible, target completion date, resources required, and how effectiveness will be verified.

Communicate corrective actions to all relevant staff. If the corrective action involves procedural changes, all affected staff must be informed and trained on new procedures. If the action addresses systemic issues, communicate broadly about what is being done and why. Effective communication reinforces that non-conformities are taken seriously and that the organization is committed to continuous improvement. Track implementation progress — for actions requiring extended time, schedule interim progress reviews to ensure actions remain on track.

subsections.heading: 4.3 Verification of Effectiveness
subsections.content:
Verification confirms that corrective actions actually solved the problem and prevented recurrence. Verification methods depend on the non-conformity and corrective action: monitor the same parameter that revealed the original non-conformity to verify it now complies, conduct targeted audits or inspections of the area or process where the non-conformity occurred, review subsequent monitoring records for evidence of sustained compliance, or conduct microbiological testing if the non-conformity involved hygiene or contamination issues.

Verification should be conducted after a reasonable period allowing the corrective action to become established — typically 2-4 weeks after implementation. Document verification results. If verification shows the problem persists, the corrective action was inadequate and additional investigation and action are required. If verification shows the problem is resolved, the non-conformity can be closed. However, continue periodic monitoring as part of routine verification — some problems may appear solved initially but recur over time if underlying causes were not fully addressed.

sections.heading: 5. Trend Analysis and Preventive Action
sections.content:
Individual non-conformity management addresses specific incidents, but trend analysis of multiple non-conformities reveals systematic issues requiring preventive action. Trending involves analyzing non-conformity data over time to identify patterns: Are certain types of non-conformities increasing? Are non-conformities concentrated in particular areas, processes, or shifts? Are the same root causes appearing repeatedly? Trends that might be invisible in individual incidents become apparent when data are aggregated and analyzed.

Trend analysis should be performed regularly — monthly or quarterly depending on the volume of non-conformities. Review should be part of management review meetings. Analyze data by multiple dimensions: non-conformity type, severity, location, time (shift, day of week, season), product category, and root cause. Use data visualization (charts, graphs) to make trends visible. Identified trends should trigger preventive actions addressing underlying systematic issues before they generate more non-conformities.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Data Analysis Methods
subsections.content:
Simple data analysis methods include: frequency analysis showing which non-conformity types occur most often, Pareto analysis identifying the vital few root causes responsible for the majority of non-conformities, time series analysis showing whether non-conformities are increasing or decreasing over time, and location analysis identifying hot spots where non-conformities concentrate. Cross-tabulation can reveal relationships: do temperature non-conformities occur more frequently on particular shifts suggesting training or supervision issues?

For effective analysis, non-conformities must be consistently categorized. Develop standard categories for non-conformity type (temperature control, cross-contamination, hygiene, documentation, etc.), root cause (equipment failure, training deficiency, procedure unclear, etc.), and severity (critical, major, minor). Consistent categorization enables meaningful comparison over time. Many food safety management software systems include non-conformity tracking and analysis modules that facilitate trending. Even simple spreadsheet-based tracking can support basic trend analysis if data are consistently recorded.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Interpreting Trends
subsections.content:
Not all trends indicate problems. An increase in reported non-conformities may indicate improved detection and reporting culture rather than deteriorating performance — this is positive. Conversely, decreased reported non-conformities might reflect better control, or might indicate that problems are being hidden. Consider context when interpreting trends. Compare non-conformity data with other metrics: are customer complaints also increasing? Are audit scores declining? Is staff turnover high?

Some trends are clearly concerning: increasing critical non-conformities, recurring non-conformities in the same area after corrective actions, high proportion of repeat non-conformities indicating ineffective corrective actions, or seasonal patterns suggesting process vulnerability to specific conditions. These trends demand preventive action. Other trends may be informational: non-conformities concentrated in a particular area might reflect higher activity level there rather than worse control. Analyze trends thoughtfully, considering multiple explanations, before jumping to conclusions about causes.

subsections.heading: 5.3 Preventive Actions Based on Trends
subsections.content:
Preventive actions address systematic issues revealed by trends. If temperature control non-conformities are frequent, preventive actions might include upgrading temperature monitoring systems to provide real-time alerts, increasing equipment preventive maintenance frequency, or redesigning kitchen layout to improve temperature control. If cross-contamination is a recurring theme, consider facility modifications creating better physical separation, color-coding equipment and utensils by use, or enhancing supervision during preparation.

If documentation non-conformities are common, simplify documentation systems, implement digital recording systems reducing paperwork burden, or increase training on documentation importance. If one shift shows consistently higher non-conformities than others, investigate whether supervision, training, workload, or other factors differ. Preventive actions based on trends typically require more investment than corrective actions for individual non-conformities, but they address root causes affecting multiple processes, delivering greater overall improvement. Prioritize preventive actions based on impact and feasibility.

sections.heading: 6. Integration with HACCP and Management Systems
sections.content:
Non-conformity management must be integrated into the overall HACCP-based food safety management system. HACCP plans should specify procedures for non-conformity management including detection, documentation, investigation, corrective action, and verification. Non-conformity data should be reviewed during HACCP verification and management review processes. Trends and corrective actions may trigger HACCP plan updates — if a new hazard is identified through non-conformity analysis, the HACCP plan should be revised to address it.

Non-conformity management also integrates with quality management systems. Organizations certified to ISO 22000 or FSSC 22000 have specific requirements for non-conformity and corrective action management. Even without formal certification, adopting structured approaches from quality management standards strengthens food safety systems. The goal is a unified management system where food safety, quality, and operational performance are managed holistically, with non-conformity management as a central continuous improvement mechanism.

subsections.heading: 6.1 HACCP Corrective Action Requirements
subsections.content:
EU Regulation 852/2004 requires that HACCP plans establish corrective actions to be taken when monitoring indicates that a CCP is not under control. The HACCP plan should specify for each CCP: what constitutes a deviation (when is the CCP not under control?), immediate actions to address the product (hold, rework, dispose), immediate actions to restore control of the process, investigation requirements to determine cause, and responsibility for corrective action decisions. Having pre-defined corrective actions enables rapid response when deviations occur.

However, not all corrective actions can be pre-defined. When unexpected deviations occur, the HACCP coordinator or manager must assess the situation and determine appropriate actions. Document all corrective actions taken, whether pre-defined or determined on the spot. Review corrective actions during HACCP verification: Were actions effective? Were actions taken promptly? Were root causes investigated? Use corrective action data to refine HACCP plans, updating pre-defined corrective actions based on experience.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Management Review of Non-Conformities
subsections.content:
Management review meetings should include analysis of non-conformity data. Review should cover: total number of non-conformities by type and severity, trends over time compared to previous periods, effectiveness of corrective actions, recurrence rates indicating ineffective corrections, and systemic issues requiring management attention or resource allocation. Management should evaluate whether the non-conformity management system itself is working effectively: Are non-conformities being detected and reported? Are investigations thorough? Are corrective actions effective?

Management review should also assess resource implications of non-conformity trends. If equipment failures are a frequent root cause, capital investment in replacement may be justified. If training deficiencies are common, enhanced training programs may be needed. Management has the authority and resources to address systematic issues that operational staff cannot resolve alone. Document management decisions and actions resulting from non-conformity review. Follow up at subsequent reviews to verify that management actions were implemented and effective.

subsections.heading: 6.3 Continuous Improvement Culture
subsections.content:
Effective non-conformity management requires an organizational culture that views non-conformities as improvement opportunities rather than failures to be hidden. Build this culture by: responding constructively to reported non-conformities rather than punishing reporters, celebrating effective problem-solving and improvement, making non-conformity and corrective action data visible to demonstrate transparency, involving frontline staff in investigation and corrective action development, and recognizing that all systems have non-conformities — the difference is how they are managed.

Leaders must model the desired culture. When managers acknowledge their own mistakes and implement corrective actions, staff learn that reporting problems is valued. When near-misses are reported and addressed before becoming actual non-conformities, the organization becomes proactive rather than reactive. When staff suggestions for preventive actions are implemented, engagement increases. The goal is an organization where problems are surfaced quickly, analyzed honestly, addressed effectively, and used as springboards for continuous improvement. This culture is the foundation of a resilient food safety system.

checklists.title: Non-Conformity Immediate Response Checklist
items: Non-conformity detected and supervisor immediately notified
Affected product immediately isolated and clearly labeled 'HOLD — Do Not Use'
Food safety risk assessment conducted: What hazard? Likelihood? Severity?
If food already served, document which customers may have been affected
Non-conformity report initiated with basic details (what, when, where, who)
Immediate containment actions documented
Initial assessment of disposition (safe to rework/release, or must dispose)
For critical non-conformities: manager and HACCP coordinator notified immediately
Product disposition decision made and documented based on risk assessment
Non-conforming product disposed of, reworked, or clearly segregated pending further investigation

checklists.title: Non-Conformity Investigation and Corrective Action Checklist
items: Complete non-conformity report with all required details
Severity classification assigned (critical, major, minor)
Root cause investigation conducted using appropriate method (5 Whys, fishbone, etc.)
Contributing factors identified beyond immediate cause
Corrective action plan developed addressing both product and process
Corrective actions are specific, measurable, and time-bound (SMART)
Responsibility for each action clearly assigned
Resources required identified and allocated
Timeline for implementation established
Communication plan for affected staff developed
Verification method and timing defined
HACCP plan reviewed for potential updates based on non-conformity

checklists.title: Monthly Non-Conformity Trend Review Checklist
items: All non-conformities from period compiled and categorized
Frequency analysis by type, severity, location, and root cause completed
Trends compared to previous periods (increasing, stable, decreasing?)
Pareto analysis identifying most frequent types and root causes
Recurrence analysis identifying repeat non-conformities in same areas/processes
Corrective action effectiveness evaluated (were actions implemented? Did they work?)
Systematic issues requiring preventive action identified
Findings prepared for presentation at management review meeting
Preventive action recommendations developed for identified trends
HACCP plan review scheduled if trends indicate new hazards or control failures

bestPractices: Create a non-punitive reporting culture where staff feel safe reporting problems without fear of blame — this surfaces issues early
Respond to every non-conformity, no matter how minor, with documentation and investigation — small problems ignored become large problems
Focus root cause investigation on system factors not individual blame — most failures result from process/equipment/training issues, not malicious intent
Implement corrective actions promptly and verify effectiveness — delayed or unverified actions allow problems to recur
Use trend analysis to move from reactive to proactive — identify and address systematic issues before they generate more non-conformities
Make non-conformity data visible through dashboards or reports that show trends and actions — transparency builds accountability
Include frontline staff in investigation and corrective action development — those closest to the work often have the best improvement ideas
View non-conformities as improvement opportunities and learning experiences, not as failures — this mindset drives continuous improvement

glossary.Non-Conformity: Failure to meet a specified requirement, including legal requirements, HACCP plan requirements, internal standards, or customer specifications
glossary.Critical Non-Conformity: Non-conformity that poses immediate food safety risk or violates critical food safety requirements
glossary.Corrective Action: Action taken to eliminate the cause of a detected non-conformity and prevent recurrence
glossary.Preventive Action: Action taken to eliminate the cause of a potential non-conformity or other potential undesirable situation before it occurs
glossary.Root Cause: The fundamental underlying reason that, if eliminated, would prevent recurrence of the non-conformity
glossary.Containment: Immediate action to isolate and control non-conforming product to prevent it reaching customers
glossary.Disposition: Decision about what to do with non-conforming product (release, rework, alternative use, or dispose)
glossary.Verification: Confirmation through provision of objective evidence that specified requirements have been fulfilled, including verification that corrective actions were effective
glossary.Trend Analysis: Analysis of data over time to identify patterns, increases, decreases, or systematic issues
glossary.5 Whys: Investigative technique that repeatedly asks 'why' to drill down from symptoms to root cause
